ArticleInfo.ArticleTitle: Dynamics of mid-infrared femtosecond laser resonant ablation

Affiliation.OrgDivision: Ultrafast Laser Laboratory, Key Laboratory of Opto-electronic Information Technology (Ministry of Education), College of Precision Instrument and Optoelectronics Engineering

Abstract.Heading: Abstract
Abstract.Para: Resonant ablation is beneficial to avoiding uncontrollable subsurface damages in the laser ablation of polymers. In this paper the dynamics of mid-infrared laser resonant ablation of polylactic acid and toluene was calculated by using fluid dynamic equations. The merits and drawbacks of mid-infrared femtosecond laser resonant ablation of high molecular weight polymers have been discussed.

Section1.Heading: Introduction
Section1.Para: Recently femtosecond (fs) laser has become a powerful new tool for microfabricating metals and inorganic materials [1–3]. However it is a challenge to cut low melting point polymers by using fs lasers. Laser always produces melted or heaved edges which blur the designed patterns even though the center of the ablation area of polymer films can be cleanly removed employing ultraviolet (UV) or near-infrared ultrashort laser [4, 5]. The previous results of the microfabrication of PLA (bulk material) in our lab had shown great troubles that melting always precedes cutting.

Is it possible to form fine patterns in polymers by ultrashort pulse laser? To answer this question, the dynamics of near-infrared fs pulse ablation need to be discussed. The multiphotos absorption is always applied for explaining the process of near-infrared fs laser ablation. The material is transparent at laser wavelength and the nonlinear absorption depends on laser intensity [6]. Consequently the absorption only happens in the focus regime, which is inside the material. Then plasma or gas from the radical reaction (photochemical reaction) [7] can generate a bubble and the breakage of the bubble will impact the material around the focus regime. Unfortunately the hardness of the polymer is much lower than glasses or inorganic materials. The consequent deformation of this impact cannot be easily estimated and controlled. For getting fine patterns, the bubble rising must be interrupted in the laser ablation of polymers. It means the complete surface ablation is required, which can be attained by adjusting laser wavelength to fit some characteristic wavelengths of the polymer within the ultraviolet band or mid-infrared band. For UV laser resonant ablation, there are two processes, photochemical process and photothermal process, on different time scales. There had been only a few papers about UV laser resonant ablation of metals [8]. Most of previous experimental results of UV ultrashort laser ablation of polymers (266 and 355 nm) were not really a resonant ablation because UV laser sources are insufficient [4]. The harmful thermal effect in our previous experiments cannot exclude the prospect of UV fs laser microfabrication because 260 nm wavelength we used is also deviated from the wavelength corresponding to Norrish reaction of PLA [9]. We think it is another interesting subject for fs laser resonant ablation but beyond this paper.

For mid-infrared laser resonant ablation, there is only photophysical process in a wide intensity range because multiphotos excitation usually needs more than 10 photos [6, 10]. Only local phonon states within ground electronic states will be excited when the wavelength of laser is the same as a certain molecular characteristic wavelength of the polymer in the mid-infrared region. It is a pure physical process without any by-product caused by a radical reaction (toxic for some polymers) in the photochemical process. There are several papers that reported the directly resonant mid-infrared pulse laser evaporation of polymers and the resonant mid-infrared matrix-assisted pulse laser evaporation (MAPLE) of polymers [11, 12]. Bubb et al. [11] compared the results of resonant and non-resonant infrared excitation and demonstrated the resonant ablation can avoid the subsurface damage. To our knowledge there are few papers which gives the detailed dynamics of the laser resonant ablation [13]. In this paper we investigate the dynamics of resonant infrared laser ablation of polylactic acid (PLA) and toluene by fluid dynamic theory and try to answer the question whether it is a good technology at microfabricating PLA with high molar mass.

Section1.Heading: Theory
Section1.Para:
Only localized anharmonic vibrational modes can be excited by mid-infrared fs laser due to very low energy of photos if adopting proper laser parameters to avoid the excitation of electrons [10]. It represents there is neither fluorescence nor photolysis, which takes place after electrons transit to excited states [7]. The polymer will be heated nearly instantaneously through intraband transitions [13]. Such a high heating speed makes the state of polymer cross the spinodal line and go into the unstable area in the phase diagram of the polymer [14]. The substance becomes homogeneous and two phases become identical at temperatures above critical temperature (T c) and pressure higher than critical pressure (P c). Therefore the ablation process can be described by fluid dynamic equations. The heating process is described by the heat conduction equation as [14],

The parameters in the generalized van der Waals equation are estimated from Lee-Kesler model because there is not a vapor phase for PLA in the equilibrium state [17]. But there is vapor phase in the non-equilibrium state within one millisecond because the thermal degradation is a much slower process than the ablation [7].

Section1.Heading: Discussion
Section1.Para:
The parameters for calculation are listed below. The wavelength is 3.4
$$\upmu$$
μ
m, which is the absorption peak of PLA [18]. The absorption index is 777 cm−1, which is from the measured mid-infrared absorption spectrum of 32
$$\upmu$$
μ
m PLA film. The temperature of the surface layer is 1,800 K after laser heats the material. The heat capacity of PLA is 3.0 J/g/K [19]. The circumstance of the ablation is in vacuum. The temperature of the circumstance is 300 K. The temperature of the phase explosion onset is 0.85 T c for solid target due to the discussions in Ref. [13] and Ref. [20]. Polymers do not have boiling points because polymers decompose before they reach a theoretical boiling point. To compare melting points, T c of polymers[21] and characteristic parameters of PLA and polymers in the lattice-fluid equation of state [22], we believe the T c of PLA is 850–950 K. So the temperature of phase explosion onset is about 800 K and the thickness of the ablated layers is about 14
$$\upmu$$
μ
m. The position of the surface (the first layer) is zero and they are positive for other layers at the initial moment.

To compare with the experimental results of the deposition [12], firstly the molar mass of PLA is set as 8,500. The temperature and the pressure exponentially decay (not shown) with depths due to the Beer-Lambert law. The pressure forces are outward forces and the interior layers will start ejection one by one. It is a surface ablation so the deformation induced by the explosion is strongly suppressed.

As Fig. 1 shows the densities of the surface (the first layer) and the last layer drop by half within 100 ns and 600 ns, respectively. The normalized densities of ablated layers are <5 % at 3,000 ns. Figure 2 shows the changes of the normalized densities of the surface and the last layer with time. The surface density decreases faster than the last layer density in the initial stages of the expansion and both become much the same value after 800 ns.
Fig. 1
The density of PLA plume at different time, M = 8,500
Fig. 2
The density variation of the first layer and the last layer with time, M = 8,500

Figure 3 shows the distribution of the plume density at 3,000 ns. There exist two discontinuity interfaces owing to the formation of the shock wave. The evolution of these discontinuity interfaces does not influence on the densities of the layers between the surface layer and the last layer. Supposing the velocity of expansion of the front keeps uniform and the distance between PLA target and the substrate is several centimeters, we can estimate that the deposition will start on several hundred microsecond scale. The temperatures of the plume keep above the thermal degradation temperature (200 °C for PLA) when the front of the plume arrives at the substrate. It comes to the conclusion that the degradation reported in Ref. [12] is unavoidable and the direct laser deposition is not suitable for thermal degradable polymers.
Fig. 3
The density of PLA plume at 3,000 ns, M = 8,500

MAPLE can avoid the thermal degradation of the polymer by heating the cryogenic solvent target instead, for example, toluene. The parameters of toluene are from Ref. [13]. The surface temperature is 1,000 K, absorption index is 3,025 cm−1 corresponding 3.31
$$\upmu$$
μ
m and the temperature of phase explosion onset is 550 K. As Fig. 4 shows the density of small solvent molecular changes much faster than polymer because of high pressure induced high velocity. Figure 5 shows a fast cooling during the phase explosion. The temperature of solvent plume becomes below the thermal degradation temperature of PLA in several tens nanoseconds because most of internal energy of molecule transfers to kinetic energy (in Fig. 5). Considering the temperature of residue liquid solvent in the target, the choice principle of the solvent for MAPLE is the temperature of phase explosive onset should be below the thermal degradation temperature of polymer. The cryogenic target in MAPLE is the best deposition technique of the polymers with low thermal degradation temperature.
Fig. 4
Toluene density of the first layer and the last layer with time
Fig. 5
Toluene temperature of the first layer and the last layer with time

The evolution of toluene plume is much more obvious due to high velocity (in Fig. 6). The front of plume moves forward with keeping discontinuity and the density of the front will become higher than the last layer in several microseconds. The calculation results are coincident with the experimental results of the shock wave evolution [23]. The temperature of a thin layer of the front increases because there is a dynamic compression process (not shown). Therefore the distance between the target and the substrate is an important parameter for MAPLE, which need to be adjusted basing on experimental results.
Fig. 6
Evolution of toluene plume with time

We are interested in the possibility of microfabricating polymers with large molar mass by mid-infrared fs laser resonant ablation, which is the material of a new generation cardiac stent. The high molecular weight PLA is hard to cut by near-infrared fs laser, i.e. 800 or 1,040 nm. There are two critical points: the dynamics of the plume’s expansion and the residual temperature of polymer around the ablation region. It is important for polymers with high molar mass that the ablation should be in vacuum because the critical pressures of such polymers are much lower than one atmospheric pressure [21]. Figure 7 shows the plume’s expansion of PLA (M = 512,000). The density of the last layer begins to decrease after 4
$$\upmu$$
μ
s and becomes nearly the same value as the surface’s after 6
$$\upmu$$
μ
s. Then the plume expands slowly due to high molecular weight. The possibility of microfabricating extra high molecular weight polymers (bulk) by the laser resonant ablation also depends on the residual temperature of the polymer around the ablated region. The residual temperature changes following the heat conduction equation and drops below the melting point of PLA after one millisecond (not shown). Such a long thermal diffusion time means high accumulated temperature caused by multi-pulses ablation even though employing one kilohertz fs laser. It is why melting precedes cutting in our previous cutting experiments (unpublished). Moreover, it must trigger the degradation of PLA in some degree. Remembering the slow startup of the expansion discussed above, a single pulse or a burst of fs pulses is suitable for high molecular weight PLA. The duration of the burst should be <5
$$\upmu$$
μ
s and the time interval of the ablation on the same position must be more than one second, which can be achieved through carefully controlling the scanning speed and route.
Fig. 7
Density variation of first layer and last layer with time, M = 512,000

In addition, there are some advantages of mid-infrared laser resonant ablating polymer films. Depending on our results, it is possible to ablate <20
$$\upmu$$
μ
m PLA film without degradation by a single pulse with selected wavelength and energy. The ablation will be accelerated by suspending the polymer film for causing the bidirectional jet. Another advantage is the strong material selectivity that the laser resonant ablation cannot influence on the substrate, especially if the substrate is another polymer or easily fabricated materials. Mid-infrared fs laser resonant ablation makes it possible to fabricate fine patterns in the polymer coating of another polymer.

Section1.Heading: Conclusion
Section1.Para: The dynamics of the resonant ablation process by mid-infrared fs laser pulses has been given in detail. Our results show the MAPLE is beneficial to avoiding thermal degradation of polymers. To fabricate high molecular weight polymers, the vacuum environment is necessary to assist the polymer plume in expanding. The accumulative thermal effect caused by multipulses ablation should be considered for cutting polymers, especially for cutting the bulk. In summary, depending our results, there are three key points for ablating high molecular weight polymers, (1) a vacuum environment, (2) a single pulse or very fast scanning (in the case of high repetition fs laser), (3) not fabricating the same position twice in at least one second. Besides, mid-infrared fs laser resonant ablation shows a good prospect of microfabricating polymer films, in particular, ablating the polymer coating on another polymer. The simulation of mid-infrared fs laser resonant ablation of polymer films will be reported soon.
